Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Topology Control for Enhancing the Reliability of the National Power Grid

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nowadays, fulfilling the demand for electric power is of utmost importance from economic, security, and societal standpoints. Paradoxically, there are very few control actions available to guarantee the power grid's reliability (i.e., to prevent unexpected power outages). This is due in part to the energy industry's conception of the electric transmission network as a static entity. In most situations, the corrective actions in response to a contingency event (i.e., a component failure) consist only of dispatching unused generator capacity and of starting up additional generation units. Conversely, topology control is an innovative approach that equips grid operators with the ability to switch each transmission line's on/off status. Previous research has shown that finding and implementing the best grid configuration (i.e., the best grid topology), in conjunction with the best respective generator dispatch, can decrease energy production/delivery costs. This EArly-Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award supports fundamental research to enhance both the proactive and reactive reliable operation of the power grid without costly infrastructure investments. Specifically, this research will show that controlling the grid's topology can enhance the grid's reliability. In addition, this research will also develop the procedures required to find the most reliable grid topology in response to changes in energy demand. Thus, the primary societal impact of this research is to increase the capability to prevent and resolve unexpected blackouts, which account for approximately $80 billion in losses each year for U.S. businesses and consumers. This research involves several disciplines including power systems, parallel computing and optimization.

The specific aim of this award is to enhance the transmission grid reliability. This will be accomplished by incorporating the innovative concept of topology control into representative mathematical programs to optimize the minute-by-minute operations of large-scale power systems. Specifically, the problem that needs to be solved every few minutes is a mixed integer nonlinear problem (MINLP). Three directions are planned to solve the MINLPs that arise when including topology control into the energy system's operations: (1) Combine alternative expressions for modeling alternate current power flows; (2) Devise new decomposition algorithms and combine them with parallel computing; (3) Exploit the fact that, to improve the reliability of the power grid, one needs to solve a MINLP every few minutes; however, since consecutive problem instances are very similar to each other, one can reuse several properties of previous optimal solutions (for example, binding constraints and other properties such as transmission-line switches that have been recurrently effective).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The payoffs stemming from this project include not only the obvious implications regarding the development of new techniques that enhance power grid reliability, but also direct benefits to society. Regarding the latter outcome, three students were provided vital research experience and substantial mentorship by the principal investigator (PI). The first student, a female Ph.D. student, participated in the project for one year. This student was allotted the opportunity to work closely with the PI, hone algorithm development skills, and develop skills as a researcher. Thanks in part to the student's involvement in this project; she is now an Instructional Assistant Professor at the University of Houston. The second student, a Ph.D. student who is a first generation college graduate, has participated in the project for three years. He also received invaluable experience from working on this project, resulting in a successful dissertation proposal based on some of the efforts described below. He intends to pursue a career in academia with research projects extending from the ideas generated in this project. This potentially extends the societal impacts of this project, allowing for the research guidance imparted by the PI to extend further and contribute to the development of future engineers. Finally, a third Ph.D. student participated in the project for one year. This student has had similar opportunities as the first two, gained invaluable research experience, and developed critical research skills.

The primary technical goal of this project was to develop algorithms to enhance, both proactively and reactively, the reliable operation of the power grid while foregoing prohibitively costly infrastructure investments. Specifically, the goal was to develop practical tools and algorithms to equip system operators with the ability to determine quickly which transmission lines can be switched on/off in order to enhance the system's reliability. Three primary research outcomes addressed this goal. First, we developed an algorithm for load-shed prevention via a DC transmission-switching model, and AC feasibility and reliability considerations. Second, we accelerated an existing AC transmission-switching algorithm to identify more quickly post-contingency transmission-switching solutions for load-shed prevention while also maintaining very high fidelity. Finally, we developed a data-mining algorithm that identifies transmission-switching solutions to reduce post-contingency transmission and voltage violations. The following paragraphs discuss these three research outcomes in additional detail, respectively.

We first developed a novel decision making framework for load-shed prevention. This framework identifies transmission-switching candidates by solving a DC model and subsequently ensures that these candidates satisfy AC feasibility, stability, and circuit breaker reliability requirements, which are vital to practical implementation. Moreover, this framework provides power system operators a set of switching candidates in a tree structure, allowing system operators to apply their experience to select the most preferable switching action(s): this human interaction component is critical as it addresses the societal/practitioners' barrier to implement transmission switching. In summary, this framework identifies strong, reliable transmission switching candidates and provides the user with freedom to prevent most effectively load-shed in a post-contingency context.

Next, we accelerated an existing AC optimal transmission switching optimization problem to identify more quickly post-contingency transmission switching actions to prevent load-shed. First, we relax a piecewise-linear approximation of apparent power, instead using a much less computationally costly linear outer-approximation. Next, we relaxed a costly piecewise-linear approximation of the cosine function by using information from the pre-contingency state and trigonometric identities; this allowed us to replace several constraints with a single, simple constraint. Finally, we allowed our optimization model to have unequal power factors for active and reactive power demand. These three relaxations substantially reduce the runtime while maintaining extremely high accuracy to identify transmission-switching solutions for load-shed prevention. This research outcome is important because it enhances the aforementioned decision making framework by replacing the highly inaccurate DC model and the need for checking AC feasibility.

Finally, we developed a data-mining model to identify transmission-switching solutions that reduce post-contingency transmission and voltage violations. To do so, we utilized real-world power system data: a set of representative load profiles and critical contingencies identified by the independent system operator. We leveraged the fact that each instance (i.e., each potential pairing of load profile and critical contingency) is highly similar to other instances with similar load profiles and/or contingencies, and thus, are ripe for using data mining techniques. Therefore, we trained a logistic regression model to identify strong transmission-switching solutions to reduce post-contingency violations. This model significantly outperforms existing distance-based heuristics both in terms of the strength of solution and necessary search depth to identify the optimal transmission switching solutions. This research outcome is important because it can be combined with the previous research outcomes by significantly accelerating the solution of the AC optimal transmission switching optimization problem. Specifically, with this data-mining model, one can reduce significantly the number of transmission lines to consider when solving the AC optimal transmission switching optimization problem.
